awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Institute in Research Methods for Professional Development for Emerging Education Researchers (PEER) Field Schools
awd_abstract_narration:
This Institute in Research Methods project extends the impact of the Professional Development for Emerging Education Researchers (PEER) field school model to emerging education researchers through a multi-faceted approach, building individual and community capacity for high-quality STEM education research. The institute advances understanding of the effectiveness of professional development for research. Evaluation activities will identify characteristics of successful field schools in STEM education research and compare these with current understanding of professional development in a pedagogical context. In addition to training the institute will contribute to generalized knowledge of how to help emerging researchers generate high quality STEM education research. 

This project consists of gateway workshops to attract and motivate participants, 5-day introductory field schools across the country, and advanced activities that explore quantitative and qualitative methodologies in depth. Curated web repositories of research tools and "Expert How To" articles will be developed with user-design research to ensure usability. These products will be hosted on the nationally established PhysPort repository for physics pedagogical resources. The project also develops a strategic partnership with the University of Virgin Islands, a public, Historically Black College, and its Institute for STEM Education Research and Practice. The final project outcome will be a growing community of discipline-based STEM education researchers trained to address critical issues in the education system, including broadening participation, addressing gaps in STEM learning, and developing the next-generation of pedagogical materials that increase student learning.

This research institute is funded by ECR (the core research program of the Education and Human Resources directorate) and attends specifically to critical aspects in research capacity building.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported the expansion of the PEER (Professional development for Emerging Education Researchers) Institute to broaden participation in education research. PEER workshops and field schools are built around topical modules with a flexible curriculum that can respond to the needs of individual participants and local communities. Participants work in a supportive community to develop their own research projects along several overlapping arcs: building fundamental skills, research design, and research communication.

As a result of this funding, the PEER Institute expanded field school offerings by hosting:

  • Five (5) national field schools (three in Rochester, NY and two in Chicago, IL),

  • Three (3) regional field schools (two in Southern California and one in the US Virgin Islands),

  • Two (2) Advanced Institutes on specific methodologies (Qualitative analysis of video data and Social network analysis),

  • Ten (10) gateway workshops (seven virtual and three in-person), and 

  • our first (1) virtual Convening for previous field school participants.

While not directly funded by the project, an additional eight (8) regional or disciplinary field schools benefited from the materials developed by the Institute. 

Significant project infrastructure was developed, including an Institute website, formalized modules with associated facilitator notes, and supplemental readings for participants. In addition, the Institute more than doubled the number of facilitators, greatly increasing the capacity to offer field schools around the country.

We have had over 600 participants, with over 200 individuals participating in at least one in-person field school. Participants are remarkably equitable across disciplinary boundaries and institution types and field schools are particularly attractive to isolated researchers and those from historically isolated and under-resourced institutions. After participating in a PEER field school, participants have produced a total of 114 publications and there have been 24 funded grants (totaling $16.6M) with a PEER participant as PI or Co-PI.

Funding to DePaul University was used to host two national field schools in Chicago, drawing participants from around the country, and to fund the participation of PEER Director Mary Bridget Kustusch in other national and regional field schools around the country.

Funding to Kansas State University was used to fund participation of PEER Directors and facilitators in national and regional field schools and postdoctoral and graduate student researchers conducting new evaluation, assessment, and research on the Institute. 

Funding to Rochester Institute of Technology was used to support participants at national and regional field schools in New York, San Diego and the US Virgin Islands, and to support undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral research on the Institute’s effectiveness
